caption: Table 1: Comparison with previous dataset distillation methods (bottom: matching-based, top: others) on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100 and Tiny ImageNet. ConvNet is used for the distillation and evaluation. Our method consistently outperforms prior matching-based methods.
description: This table compares the proposed PAD method with other state-of-the-art dataset distillation methods on three benchmark datasets: CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny ImageNet.  The comparison is done across various compression ratios (represented by IPC values) and shows the accuracy achieved by each method.  The table highlights that PAD consistently outperforms other matching-based methods, demonstrating its effectiveness in dataset distillation.

caption: Table 1: Comparison with previous dataset distillation methods (bottom: matching-based, top: others) on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100 and Tiny ImageNet. ConvNet is used for the distillation and evaluation. Our method consistently outperforms prior matching-based methods.
description: This table compares the performance of PAD against several other state-of-the-art dataset distillation methods on three benchmark datasets: CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny ImageNet.  It shows the accuracy achieved by each method across various compression ratios (IPC) for a convolutional neural network (ConvNet).  The table highlights that PAD consistently outperforms other matching-based methods, demonstrating its effectiveness in distilling high-quality synthetic datasets.

caption: Table 3: (a) Cross-Architecture evaluation on CIFAR-100 IPC50. (b) Ablation studies on the modules of our method on CIFAR-10 IPC10. (c) Results of different sets of data selection hyper-parameters on CIFAR-10 IPC10.
description: This table presents the results of experiments evaluating the generalization ability of datasets distilled by the proposed PAD method across different network architectures. It also shows the results of ablation studies conducted to investigate the individual contributions of the two modules in PAD, and the impact of different hyperparameter settings on the performance.

caption: Table 4: (a) Ablation of different difficulty scoring functions on CIFAR-10. (b) Results of masking out different ratios of shallow-layer parameters across various IPCs on CIFAR-10. (c) Ablation on the strategy used for parameter selection on CIFAR-10
description: This table presents the ablation study on the difficulty scoring functions, the effect of removing different ratios of shallow-layer parameters, and the parameter selection strategies used in the PAD method. It shows the impact of each component on the performance across different IPCs (Information Preservation Capacity) on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

caption: Table 4: (a) Ablation of different difficulty scoring functions on CIFAR-10. (b) Results of masking out different ratios of shallow-layer parameters across various IPCs on CIFAR-10. (c) Ablation on the strategy used for parameter selection on CIFAR-10
description: This table presents the ablation study results on CIFAR-10 dataset. It shows the impact of different difficulty scoring functions, different ratios of shallow-layer parameters masking, and different parameter selection strategies on the model's performance. The results are categorized into three parts: (a) compares the performance of different difficulty scoring functions, (b) shows the effect of masking out different ratios of shallow-layer parameters on model performance, and (c) compares different strategies for selecting the parameters used in the model.

caption: Table 4: (a) Ablation of different difficulty scoring functions on CIFAR-10. (b) Results of masking out different ratios of shallow-layer parameters across various IPCs on CIFAR-10. (c) Ablation on the strategy used for parameter selection on CIFAR-10
description: This table presents the ablation study results on three different aspects of the PAD method. (a) compares three different difficulty scoring functions used for data selection. (b) shows how different ratios of shallow-layer parameters being masked affect the performance with various IPCs. (c) compares different strategies used for parameter selection.

caption: Table 5: Results of filtering information extraction by removing hard/easy samples in DC(a) and DM(b) on CIFAR-10.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the information extraction step of dataset distillation methods, specifically Deep Convolutional Networks (DC) and Distribution Matching (DM), using the CIFAR-10 dataset.  The study investigates the impact of removing different proportions of either "hard" or "easy" samples from the training data on the final model performance. The table shows that removing a portion of the samples leads to improvements in performance, particularly at both small and large IPCs (Image Per Class) indicating that removing samples that are not relevant or beneficial to the learning process positively affects the performance.

caption: Table 5: Results of filtering information extraction by removing hard/easy samples in DC(a) and DM(b) on CIFAR-10.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the information extraction step of dataset distillation using the CIFAR-10 dataset.  Two methods, DC (matching gradients) and DM (matching distributions), are evaluated.  Different ratios of "hard" and "easy" samples are removed from the dataset before distillation, and the resulting accuracy is measured.  The goal is to determine the impact of removing certain data points on the performance of the distillation process and to show that filtering out certain samples based on their difficulty improves the quality of synthetic data.

caption: Table 6: Results of filtering information embedding by masking out shallow-layer parameters for metric computation in DC(a) and DM(b) on CIFAR-10.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the impact of removing shallow-layer parameters from the metric computation in the dataset distillation methods DC and DM, evaluated on CIFAR-10. It shows how varying the proportion of shallow-layer parameters affects the performance for different IPCs (Image Per Class) values of 10 and 500. The baseline results represent the performance without removing any parameters.  The table demonstrates that appropriately removing shallow layer parameters improves the performance of both DC and DM across different IPCs.

caption: Table 6: Results of filtering information embedding by masking out shallow-layer parameters for metric computation in DC(a) and DM(b) on CIFAR-10.
description: This table shows the results of applying the information embedding filtering technique (masking out shallow-layer parameters) to the DC and DM methods on the CIFAR-10 dataset.  Different ratios (25%, 50%, 75%) of shallow-layer parameters were masked out, and the impact on performance is measured and compared to a baseline where no parameters were masked.

caption: Table 1: Comparison with previous dataset distillation methods (bottom: matching-based, top: others) on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100 and Tiny ImageNet. ConvNet is used for the distillation and evaluation. Our method consistently outperforms prior matching-based methods.
description: This table compares the proposed PAD method with other state-of-the-art dataset distillation methods on three benchmark datasets: CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny ImageNet.  The comparison is done using a ConvNet for both distillation and evaluation. The table shows that PAD achieves better results than other matching-based methods, especially at higher compression ratios.
